If the product of the opposites of two elements has at most one representation as a product of elements from two sets under multiplication, then the product of the original elements has at most one representation as a product of an element from each set.

    UniqueMul A B a0 b0
name: UniqueMul.of_mulOpposite
docString: If the product of the opposites of two elements has at most one representation as a product of elements from two sets under multiplication, then the product of the original elements has at most one representation as a product of an element from each set.

This theorem is known as the *Euler Product* for completely multiplicative functions. If you have a completely multiplicative function `f` from natural numbers to a complete normed field `F`, and the norm of `f` is summable (i.e., the series of the norms of `f` converges), then the product over all prime numbers `p` of `(1 - f p)â»Â¹` converges to the sum over all natural numbers `n` of `f n`. Concretely, this says the infinite product `âˆ' p : Nat.Primes, (1 - f p)â»Â¹` equals the infinite sum `âˆ‘' n, f n`. This theorem is stated in the form of convergence of finite partial products, meaning that as you consider more and more terms in the product, the value of the product gets closer and closer to the value of the infinite sum.

type:
âˆ€ {F : Type u_1} [inst : NormedField F] [inst_1 : CompleteSpace F] {f : â„• â†’*â‚€ F},
  (Summable fun x => â€–f xâ€–) â†’
    Filter.Tendsto (fun n => n.primesBelow.prod fun p => (1 - f p)â»Â¹) Filter.atTop (nhds (âˆ‘' (n : â„•), f n))
name: EulerProduct.eulerProduct_completely_multiplicative
docString: This theorem is known as the *Euler Product* for completely multiplicative functions. If you have a completely multiplicative function `f` from natural numbers to a complete normed field `F`, and the norm of `f` is summable (i.e., the series of the norms of `f` converges), then the product over all prime numbers `p` of `(1 - f p)â»Â¹` converges to the sum over all natural numbers `n` of `f n`. Concretely, this says the infinite product `âˆ' p : Nat.Primes, (1 - f p)â»Â¹` equals the infinite sum `âˆ‘' n, f n`. This theorem is stated in the form of convergence of finite partial products, meaning that as you consider more and more terms in the product, the value of the product gets closer and closer to the value of the infinite sum.

This theorem states that for all integers `a` and `b`, the product of the negations of `a` and `b` (i.e., `-a * -b`) is equal to the product of `a` and `b` (i.e., `a * b`). This is a formal expression of the mathematical rule that the product of two negative numbers is a positive number.

This is a formal expression of the mathematical rule that the product of two negative numbers is a positive number.
